Aarskog syndrome.disease_detail: Aarskog syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by short stature, facial abnormalities, and genital anomalies. It predominantly affects males and is associated with mutations in the FGD1 gene.
cause: Mutations in the FGD1 gene.
X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.
symptoms: Short stature and delayed growth.
Facial features such as a round face, wide-set eyes, and a small nose.
Genital anomalies, including undescended testes.
Brachydactyly (short fingers and toes).
Mild to moderate intellectual disability.
prevention: Genetic counseling for families with a history of Aarskog syndrome.
Prenatal genetic testing and diagnosis.
treatment: Growth hormone therapy to promote height gain.
Surgical correction of genital anomalies.
Physical therapy to improve muscle strength and coordination.
Special education and developmental support for intellectual disabilities.

Aase syndrome.disease_detail: Aase syndrome is a rare congenital disorder characterized by anemia and skeletal abnormalities, particularly involving the fingers and thumbs. The condition is typically diagnosed in infancy.
cause: Genetic mutations, though the exact genes involved are often unknown.
Possible autosomal recessive inheritance.
symptoms: Severe anemia with low red blood cell counts.
Thumb abnormalities (underdeveloped or missing thumbs).
Pale skin and fatigue due to anemia.
Congenital heart defects.
prevention: Genetic counseling for families with a history of Aase syndrome.
Prenatal genetic testing and diagnosis.
treatment: Blood transfusions to manage severe anemia.
Bone marrow transplantation in severe cases.
Surgical correction of skeletal abnormalities.
Ongoing monitoring and treatment of heart defects.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm.disease_detail: An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is an enlargement of the lower part of the aorta, the major blood vessel that supplies blood to the body, which can lead to life-threatening bleeding if it ruptures.
cause: Atherosclerosis (buildup of plaque in the arteries).
Genetic factors and family history.
High blood pressure (hypertension).
Smoking.
symptoms: Often asymptomatic until it ruptures.
A pulsating feeling near the navel.
Deep, constant pain in the abdomen or side.
Back pain.
prevention: Regular screening for at-risk individuals (e.g., men over 65 who have smoked).
Maintain healthy blood pressure levels.
Avoid smoking and tobacco use.
Healthy diet and regular exercise.
treatment: Regular monitoring and ultrasound exams for small aneurysms.
Medications to control blood pressure and cholesterol.
Surgical repair for large or symptomatic aneurysms, including endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) or open surgical repair.

Abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB).disease_detail: Abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) is irregular bleeding from the uterus that is not related to regular menstruation. It can include heavy menstrual bleeding, bleeding between periods, or bleeding after menopause.
cause: Hormonal imbalances, such as those caused by polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or thyroid disorders.
Uterine fibroids or polyps.
Endometriosis or adenomyosis.
Pregnancy-related complications.
Cancer of the uterus or cervix.
symptoms: Heavy menstrual bleeding.
Bleeding or spotting between periods.
Menstrual cycles that are longer than 35 days or shorter than 21 days.
Bleeding after menopause.
prevention: Maintain a healthy weight and lifestyle.
Regular gynecological exams and screenings.
Manage underlying conditions such as PCOS or thyroid disorders.
Use of birth control pills or hormone therapy as prescribed.
treatment: Hormonal treatments, such as birth control pills or hormone therapy.
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain and to reduce bleeding.
Surgical options, including dilation and curettage (D&C), endometrial ablation, or hysterectomy for severe cases.
Treatment of underlying conditions, such as fibroids or polyps.

Acetaminophen and codeine overdose.disease_detail: An overdose of acetaminophen and codeine occurs when someone takes more than the normal or recommended amount of these medications, leading to potentially life-threatening symptoms affecting the liver, central nervous system, and respiratory function.
cause: Accidental ingestion of high doses.
Intentional overdose for self-harm or suicide.
Incorrect dosing or misunderstanding of medication instructions.
symptoms: Nausea and vomiting.
Severe drowsiness or confusion.
Liver damage, indicated by jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes).
Respiratory depression (slowed or difficulty breathing).
Coma or death in severe cases.
prevention: Follow prescribed dosages carefully.
Store medications securely away from children and others who might misuse them.
Avoid mixing medications without consulting a healthcare provider.
Seek help for mental health issues to prevent intentional overdose.
treatment: Activated charcoal to limit drug absorption if presented early.
N-acetylcysteine (NAC) as an antidote for acetaminophen toxicity.
Naloxone to counteract opioid effects, especially respiratory depression.
Supportive care in an intensive care unit for severe cases.

Acetone poisoning.disease_detail: Acetone poisoning occurs when someone is exposed to high levels of acetone, a solvent commonly found in nail polish remover, paint thinner, and other household products, leading to symptoms affecting the central nervous system and respiratory system.
cause: Inhalation of acetone fumes.
Ingestion of acetone-containing products.
Prolonged skin contact with acetone.
symptoms: Headache and dizziness.
Nausea and vomiting.
Confusion and lethargy.
Respiratory distress.
Loss of consciousness in severe cases.
prevention: Use acetone-containing products in well-ventilated areas.
Keep acetone products out of reach of children.
Wear protective gloves and masks when handling acetone.
Follow safety guidelines and label instructions.
treatment: Removal from the source of exposure.
Administration of oxygen for respiratory distress.
Intravenous fluids to prevent dehydration.
Supportive care and monitoring in a hospital setting.

Achalasia.disease_detail: Achalasia is a rare disorder of the esophagus, characterized by difficulty swallowing and the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax properly, leading to food backing up in the esophagus.
cause: Degeneration of nerves in the esophagus.
Autoimmune factors.
Genetic predisposition in some cases.
symptoms: Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia).
Regurgitation of undigested food.
Chest pain or discomfort.
Weight loss and malnutrition.
Heartburn or acid reflux.
prevention: No known prevention as the exact cause is often unclear.
Early diagnosis and management to prevent complications.
treatment: Pneumatic dilation to widen the esophagus.
Botox injections to relax the lower esophageal sphincter.
Medications such as nitrates or calcium channel blockers to reduce sphincter pressure.
Surgical options like Heller myotomy to cut the muscles at the lower esophageal sphincter.

Achondrogenesis.disease_detail: Achondrogenesis is a group of severe disorders characterized by abnormal development of cartilage and bone, leading to dwarfism and other skeletal abnormalities. It is typically diagnosed prenatally or at birth.
cause: Genetic mutations in the SLC26A2 gene (Type 1B) or COL2A1 gene (Type 2).
Autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.
symptoms: Severe shortening of the limbs.
Small chest with underdeveloped lungs.
Prominent abdomen.
Facial abnormalities.
Usually fatal in the perinatal period.
prevention: Genetic counseling for at-risk families.
Prenatal genetic testing and diagnosis.
treatment: Supportive care for respiratory and feeding difficulties.
Genetic counseling for the family.
Palliative care in cases with poor prognosis.

Achondroplasia.disease_detail: Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder that is the most common cause of dwarfism. It is characterized by short stature, with disproportionately short arms and legs, and a large head with a prominent forehead.
cause: Mutations in the FGFR3 gene.
Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, though most cases result from new mutations.
symptoms: Short stature with short arms and legs.
Large head with a prominent forehead.
Midface hypoplasia (underdeveloped facial bones).
Spinal stenosis and lordosis.
Normal intelligence.
prevention: Genetic counseling for families with a history of achondroplasia.
Prenatal genetic testing for at-risk pregnancies.
treatment: Growth hormone therapy to increase height in children.
Surgical intervention for spinal stenosis or other skeletal abnormalities.
Physical therapy to improve strength and mobility.
Regular monitoring for complications such as hydrocephalus and ear infections.

Acid soldering flux poisoning.disease_detail: Acid soldering flux poisoning occurs when someone is exposed to the toxic chemicals found in soldering flux, which are used to clean and prepare metal surfaces for soldering. Ingestion or inhalation of these chemicals can lead to severe health effects.
cause: Inhalation of fumes from acid soldering flux.
Ingestion of flux materials.
Skin contact with flux containing harmful chemicals.
symptoms: Burning sensation in the mouth and throat.
Nausea and vomiting.
Difficulty breathing or respiratory distress.
Abdominal pain and diarrhea.
Chemical burns on the skin or eyes.
prevention: Use flux in well-ventilated areas.
Wear protective gear such as gloves and masks.
Store flux materials securely and away from children.
Follow safety guidelines and label instructions carefully.
treatment: Remove the person from the source of exposure.
Rinse mouth and skin thoroughly with water if exposed.
Provide oxygen for respiratory distress.
Administer activated charcoal if ingested and within appropriate time frame.
Hospitalization and supportive care for severe cases.

Acidosis.disease_detail: Acidosis is a condition in which there is too much acid in the body fluids. It can result from an excess of acid or a significant loss of bicarbonate. There are two main types: metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis.
cause: Kidney failure leading to metabolic acidosis.
Diabetic ketoacidosis from uncontrolled diabetes.
Severe dehydration or prolonged exercise.
Lung diseases causing respiratory acidosis.
Poisoning from substances like methanol or aspirin.
symptoms: Rapid breathing (in metabolic acidosis).
Confusion or lethargy.
Fatigue and weakness.
Shortness of breath (in respiratory acidosis).
Nausea and vomiting.
prevention: Manage underlying conditions such as diabetes and lung disease.
Maintain proper hydration.
Avoid excessive consumption of substances that can cause acidosis.
Regular medical check-ups to monitor health status.
treatment: Treatment of underlying cause (e.g., insulin for diabetic ketoacidosis).
Intravenous bicarbonate in severe metabolic acidosis.
Oxygen therapy or mechanical ventilation for respiratory acidosis.
Dialysis for kidney failure-related acidosis.

Acne.disease_detail: Acne is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells. It often causes whiteheads, blackheads, or pimples, and can appear on the face, forehead, chest, upper back, and shoulders.
cause: Excess oil production.
Clogged hair follicles.
Bacteria and inflammation.
Hormonal changes, especially during puberty.
symptoms: Whiteheads (closed plugged pores).
Blackheads (open plugged pores).
Small red, tender bumps (papules).
Pimples (pustules), which are papules with pus at their tips.
Large, solid, painful lumps beneath the surface of the skin (nodules).
prevention: Wash your face twice a day with a gentle cleanser.
Avoid picking or squeezing pimples.
Use non-comedogenic skincare products.
Maintain a healthy diet and manage stress.
treatment: Over-the-counter topical treatments with benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid.
Prescription topical treatments with retinoids or antibiotics.
Oral medications like antibiotics, birth control pills, or isotretinoin.
Procedures such as chemical peels, laser therapy, or drainage and extraction.

Acoustic neuroma.disease_detail: Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, is a noncancerous tumor that develops on the eighth cranial nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. It can cause hearing loss, balance problems, and other neurological symptoms.
cause: Genetic mutations, often associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
Exposure to high doses of radiation, especially to the head.
symptoms: Hearing loss in one ear.
Ringing (tinnitus) in the affected ear.
Balance problems or unsteadiness.
Facial numbness or weakness.
Headaches.
prevention: Regular monitoring for those with a family history of neurofibromatosis type 2.
Minimize exposure to head and neck radiation.
treatment: Observation with regular MRI scans for small, asymptomatic tumors.
Surgical removal of the tumor.
Radiation therapy, such as stereotactic radiosurgery (Gamma Knife).
Hearing aids or cochlear implants for hearing loss.

Acrodysostosis.disease_detail: Acrodysostosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by skeletal malformations, particularly in the hands and feet, and facial abnormalities. It may also involve hormonal resistance and intellectual disability.
cause: Mutations in the PDE4D or PRKAR1A genes.
Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.
symptoms: Short stature.
Shortened fingers and toes with broad ends.
Facial features such as a small nose and a prominent forehead.
Developmental delays or intellectual disability.
Hormonal resistance leading to issues like hypothyroidism.
prevention: Genetic counseling for families with a history of acrodysostosis.
Prenatal genetic testing and diagnosis.
treatment: Management of hormonal issues with appropriate medications.
Physical and occupational therapy to improve mobility and function.
Special education and developmental support for intellectual disabilities.
Regular monitoring and supportive care for associated health problems.

Acromegaly.disease_detail: Acromegaly is a hormonal disorder that develops when the pituitary gland produces excessive growth hormone, usually due to a benign tumor. This leads to the enlargement of bones and tissues, particularly in the hands, feet, and face.
cause: Benign pituitary adenoma.
Rarely, non-pituitary tumors producing growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH).
symptoms: Enlarged hands and feet.
Facial changes, such as a protruding jaw and brow.
Thickened skin.
Joint pain and limited mobility.
Enlarged organs, such as the heart.
prevention: No known prevention; early diagnosis and treatment are crucial.
Regular medical check-ups and monitoring for those at risk.
treatment: Surgical removal of the pituitary tumor.
Medications to reduce growth hormone production, such as somatostatin analogs or dopamine agonists.
Radiation therapy to shrink the tumor.
Regular monitoring and management of complications.

Acute adrenal crisis.disease_detail: Acute adrenal crisis is a life-threatening condition that occurs when there is insufficient cortisol production by the adrenal glands, often due to Addison's disease or abrupt discontinuation of corticosteroid therapy.
cause: Addison's disease or adrenal insufficiency.
Abrupt discontinuation of corticosteroid therapy.
Severe infection or stress in people with adrenal insufficiency.
Adrenal gland hemorrhage.
symptoms: Severe weakness and fatigue.
Abdominal pain and nausea.
Low blood pressure and shock.
Confusion or altered mental status.
Rapid heart rate.
prevention: Proper management of adrenal insufficiency with regular medication.
Avoid abrupt discontinuation of corticosteroids without medical advice.
Prompt treatment of infections and stress management.
treatment: Intravenous hydrocortisone to replace cortisol.
Intravenous fluids to treat dehydration and low blood pressure.
Treatment of underlying causes such as infection.
Electrolyte replacement if necessary.

Acute arterial occlusion - kidney.disease_detail: Acute arterial occlusion of the kidney is a sudden blockage of the renal artery, which can lead to kidney damage or failure if not promptly treated.
cause: Embolism (blood clot traveling to the renal artery).
Thrombosis (blood clot forming in the renal artery).
Trauma to the kidney.
Atherosclerosis leading to narrowing of the renal artery.
symptoms: Severe flank or abdominal pain.
Nausea and vomiting.
Sudden decrease in urine output.
High blood pressure.
Fever.
prevention: Control risk factors like hypertension and diabetes.
Avoid smoking and maintain a healthy diet.
Regular medical check-ups to monitor kidney and vascular health.
treatment: Anticoagulant therapy to dissolve clots.
Surgical intervention such as thrombectomy or angioplasty.
Supportive care for kidney function, including dialysis if necessary.
Management of underlying conditions such as atherosclerosis.

Acute bronchitis.disease_detail: Acute bronchitis is an inflammation of the bronchial tubes in the lungs, usually caused by viral infections, which results in a cough and mucus production. It is often accompanied by cold-like symptoms.
cause: Viral infections, such as the common cold or influenza.
Bacterial infections in some cases.
Exposure to irritants like smoke, dust, or fumes.
symptoms: Persistent cough with mucus production.
Chest discomfort or soreness.
Fatigue and mild fever.
Shortness of breath or wheezing.
Sore throat and nasal congestion.
prevention: Practice good hand hygiene to avoid infections.
Avoid smoking and exposure to lung irritants.
Get vaccinated against influenza and other respiratory infections.
Maintain a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet and regular exercise.
treatment: Rest and increased fluid intake.
Over-the-counter medications to relieve symptoms, such as cough suppressants and pain relievers.
Inhalers or nebulizers for wheezing or shortness of breath.
Antibiotics if a bacterial infection is suspected.

Acute cerebellar ataxia.disease_detail: Acute cerebellar ataxia is a sudden onset of coordination and balance problems due to dysfunction in the cerebellum, often triggered by infections, autoimmune reactions, or toxic exposures.
cause: Viral infections such as chickenpox, Epstein-Barr virus, or Coxsackie virus.
Autoimmune conditions like multiple sclerosis.
Toxic exposure to substances like alcohol or certain medications.
Stroke or other brain injury.
symptoms: Unsteady gait and difficulty walking.
Clumsiness or difficulty with fine motor tasks.
Dizziness or vertigo.
Nausea and vomiting.
Slurred speech.
prevention: Vaccinations to prevent viral infections.
Avoidance of toxic substances like alcohol in excess.
Early treatment of infections and autoimmune conditions.
Regular medical check-ups to monitor neurological health.
treatment: Treatment of underlying infections or conditions.
Supportive care such as physical therapy to improve coordination.
Medications to manage symptoms like dizziness and nausea.
Monitoring and supportive care in severe cases.

Acute cholecystitis.disease_detail: Acute cholecystitis is the inflammation of the gallbladder, typically caused by gallstones blocking the cystic duct. This condition can lead to severe pain and requires prompt medical treatment.
cause: Gallstones obstructing the cystic duct.
Bacterial infection in the gallbladder.
Tumor blocking the cystic duct.
Bile duct problems or injury.
symptoms: Severe pain in the upper right abdomen.
Pain that radiates to the right shoulder or back.
Fever and chills.
Nausea and vomiting.
Tenderness over the abdomen when touched.
prevention: Maintain a healthy weight and avoid rapid weight loss.
Follow a balanced diet low in fat and high in fiber.
Stay hydrated and exercise regularly.
Manage underlying conditions like diabetes.
treatment: Hospitalization for observation and treatment.
Fasting to rest the gallbladder.
Intravenous fluids and antibiotics.
Pain management with medications.
Surgical removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy) in severe cases.

Acute coronary syndrome.disease_detail: Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) is a term used for situations where the blood supplied to the heart muscle is suddenly blocked, leading to conditions like unstable angina or myocardial infarction (heart attack).
cause: Atherosclerosis leading to plaque rupture and blood clot formation.
Coronary artery spasm.
Severe narrowing of coronary arteries.
symptoms: Chest pain or discomfort, often described as pressure, tightness, or squeezing.
Pain radiating to the shoulders, arms, neck, jaw, or back.
Shortness of breath.
Nausea or vomiting.
Sweating and lightheadedness.
prevention: Maintain a healthy diet and regular exercise routine.
Avoid smoking and manage stress.
Control risk factors such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and diabetes.
Regular medical check-ups to monitor heart health.
treatment: Medications such as antiplatelets, anticoagulants, beta-blockers, and statins.
Emergency procedures like angioplasty and stent placement.
Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery.
Lifestyle modifications and cardiac rehabilitation.

Acute flaccid myelitis.disease_detail: Acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) is a rare but serious neurological condition that affects the spinal cord, causing sudden weakness in the arms or legs. It can be caused by viral infections and other factors.
cause: Viral infections, particularly enteroviruses.
Other infections like West Nile virus or adenovirus.
Autoimmune responses.
symptoms: Sudden onset of arm or leg weakness.
Loss of muscle tone and reflexes.
Facial weakness or drooping.
Difficulty moving the eyes or drooping eyelids.
Difficulty swallowing or slurred speech.
prevention: Practice good hygiene to prevent viral infections.
Stay up to date with vaccinations.
Protect against mosquito bites in areas with West Nile virus.
treatment: Hospitalization for monitoring and supportive care.
Physical and occupational therapy to improve strength and function.
Medications to manage symptoms and inflammation.
Respiratory support in severe cases.

Acute kidney failure.disease_detail: Acute kidney failure, also known as acute renal failure, is a sudden loss of kidney function, which leads to the accumulation of waste products in the blood and electrolyte imbalances.
cause: Severe dehydration.
Severe infections or sepsis.
Obstruction of the urinary tract.
Exposure to nephrotoxic drugs or toxins.
symptoms: Decreased urine output.
Swelling in the legs, ankles, or feet.
Fatigue and weakness.
Shortness of breath.
Confusion or altered mental status.
prevention: Maintain adequate hydration.
Avoid medications and substances that can harm the kidneys.
Manage chronic conditions like diabetes and hypertension.
Regular medical check-ups to monitor kidney function.
treatment: Treating the underlying cause of kidney failure.
Intravenous fluids to restore fluid balance.
Medications to manage symptoms and prevent complications.
Dialysis if kidney function does not improve.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia.disease_detail: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells. It progresses rapidly and requires prompt treatment.
cause: Genetic mutations in the bone marrow cells.
Exposure to high levels of radiation.
Certain genetic disorders like Down syndrome.
symptoms: Frequent infections.
Fever and night sweats.
Easy bruising or bleeding.
Bone or joint pain.
Fatigue and weakness.
prevention: There is no known prevention for ALL.
Regular medical check-ups for early detection.
Avoid exposure to high levels of radiation and toxic chemicals.
treatment: Chemotherapy to kill cancer cells.
Radiation therapy.
Stem cell transplant.
Targeted therapy and immunotherapy.

Acute mountain sickness.disease_detail: Acute mountain sickness (AMS) occurs when the body cannot adapt quickly enough to high altitudes, typically above 8,000 feet (2,400 meters), leading to a range of symptoms due to reduced oxygen levels.
cause: Rapid ascent to high altitudes.
Lack of acclimatization.
Exertion at high altitudes.
symptoms: Headache.
Nausea and vomiting.
Dizziness or lightheadedness.
Fatigue and weakness.
Shortness of breath.
prevention: Ascend gradually to allow for acclimatization.
Stay well hydrated.
Avoid alcohol and heavy exertion at high altitudes.
Consider taking acetazolamide to help acclimatize.
treatment: Descend to a lower altitude immediately.
Rest and avoid further exertion.
Oxygen therapy to increase oxygen levels.
Medications like acetazolamide or dexamethasone to relieve symptoms.

Acute myeloid leukemia.disease_detail: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow characterized by the rapid growth of abnormal white blood cells that accumulate in the bone marrow and interfere with the production of normal blood cells.
cause: Genetic mutations in bone marrow cells.
Previous chemotherapy or radiation therapy.
Exposure to certain chemicals such as benzene.
Genetic disorders such as Down syndrome.
symptoms: Frequent infections.
Fatigue and weakness.
Easy bruising or bleeding.
Bone or joint pain.
Shortness of breath.
prevention: Avoid exposure to toxic chemicals like benzene.
Limit exposure to radiation.
Regular medical check-ups for those at risk.
Healthy lifestyle to boost immune function.
treatment: Chemotherapy to kill cancer cells.
Stem cell transplant to replace damaged bone marrow.
Targeted therapy to attack specific cancer cells.
Supportive care to manage symptoms and complications.

Acute nephritic syndrome.disease_detail: Acute nephritic syndrome is a group of symptoms caused by inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys, leading to kidney damage and impaired function.
cause: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
Autoimmune diseases such as lupus.
Infections like hepatitis or HIV.
IgA nephropathy.
symptoms: Blood in the urine (hematuria).
Protein in the urine (proteinuria).
Swelling in the face, hands, and feet (edema).
High blood pressure.
Decreased urine output.
prevention: Prompt treatment of streptococcal infections.
Manage underlying conditions like lupus.
Regular medical check-ups for those at risk.
Healthy lifestyle to support kidney function.
treatment: Treatment of underlying cause such as antibiotics for infections.
Medications to control high blood pressure.
Corticosteroids or immunosuppressive drugs for autoimmune conditions.
Dialysis in severe cases to support kidney function.

Acute pancreatitis.disease_detail: Acute pancreatitis is a sudden inflammation of the pancreas that can range from mild discomfort to a severe, life-threatening illness.
cause: Gallstones blocking the pancreatic duct.
Chronic and excessive alcohol consumption.
Certain medications and infections.
High levels of triglycerides in the blood.
symptoms: Severe upper abdominal pain that may radiate to the back.
Nausea and vomiting.
Fever.
Rapid pulse.
Tenderness and swelling in the abdomen.
prevention: Avoid excessive alcohol consumption.
Maintain a healthy diet and weight.
Treat gallstones and high triglycerides.
Avoid medications that can trigger pancreatitis, if possible.
treatment: Hospitalization for monitoring and supportive care.
Fasting to rest the pancreas.
Intravenous fluids and pain relief.
Treatment of underlying causes such as gallstone removal.
In severe cases, surgery or other interventions.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome.disease_detail: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a severe lung condition that occurs when fluid builds up in the air sacs of the lungs, leading to respiratory failure.
cause: Severe infections such as pneumonia or sepsis.
Trauma or injury to the lungs.
Inhalation of harmful substances.
Pancreatitis.
Blood transfusions.
symptoms: Severe shortness of breath.
Rapid breathing.
Low blood oxygen levels.
Cough and fever.
Confusion and fatigue.
prevention: Prevent and treat infections promptly.
Avoid smoking and exposure to lung irritants.
Manage chronic health conditions effectively.
Follow safety guidelines to avoid trauma.
treatment: Mechanical ventilation to support breathing.
Oxygen therapy to maintain adequate oxygen levels.
Medications to manage infections and reduce inflammation.
Fluid management to prevent fluid overload.
Supportive care in an intensive care unit (ICU).

Acute tubular necrosis.disease_detail: Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is a kidney disorder involving damage to the tubule cells of the kidneys, which can lead to acute kidney failure.
cause: Severe low blood pressure or shock.
Use of nephrotoxic drugs.
Severe infections or sepsis.
Surgery or trauma.
symptoms: Decreased urine output.
Swelling in the legs, ankles, and feet.
Fatigue and confusion.
Nausea and vomiting.
Shortness of breath.
prevention: Maintain adequate hydration.
Avoid nephrotoxic drugs when possible.
Treat underlying conditions such as infections promptly.
Monitor kidney function during and after major surgery.
treatment: Treatment of the underlying cause.
Intravenous fluids to maintain fluid balance.
Medications to manage symptoms and support kidney function.
Dialysis in severe cases to remove waste products.
Supportive care to prevent complications.

Addison disease.disease_detail: Addison disease, also known as primary adrenal insufficiency, is a rare disorder where the adrenal glands do not produce enough of the hormones cortisol and aldosterone.
cause: Autoimmune destruction of the adrenal glands.
Infections such as tuberculosis or HIV.
Genetic mutations affecting adrenal function.
Adrenal gland hemorrhage or cancer.
symptoms: Chronic fatigue and muscle weakness.
Weight loss and decreased appetite.
Low blood pressure and fainting.
Hyperpigmentation (darkening) of the skin.
Salt cravings.
prevention: There is no known prevention for autoimmune Addison disease.
Prompt treatment of infections and underlying conditions.
Regular monitoring and management for those at risk.
treatment: Hormone replacement therapy with corticosteroids.
Medications to manage symptoms and balance electrolytes.
Regular monitoring of hormone levels.
Medical alert identification to inform others of the condition.

Adenomyosis.disease_detail: Adenomyosis is a condition where the inner lining of the uterus (endometrium) breaks through the muscle wall of the uterus (myometrium), causing heavy menstrual bleeding and painful periods.
cause: Exact cause unknown, but linked to hormonal factors.
Previous uterine surgery, such as a C-section.
Childbirth.
Middle age and advancing reproductive age.
symptoms: Heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding.
Severe menstrual cramps or pelvic pain.
Painful intercourse.
Chronic pelvic pain.
Enlarged uterus.
prevention: There is no known prevention for adenomyosis.
Early diagnosis and management to control symptoms.
Maintain a healthy lifestyle to reduce general risk factors.
treatment: Anti-inflammatory medications to reduce pain.
Hormonal therapies to regulate menstrual cycle.
Endometrial ablation to destroy the uterine lining.
Hysterectomy in severe cases where other treatments fail.

Adhesion.disease_detail: Adhesions are bands of scar tissue that form between tissues and organs, often as a result of surgery, infection, or inflammation, leading to pain and potential complications.
cause: Surgical procedures, particularly abdominal or pelvic surgery.
Infections such as pelvic inflammatory disease.
Inflammatory conditions like endometriosis.
Radiation therapy.
symptoms: Chronic abdominal or pelvic pain.
Bowel obstruction leading to nausea, vomiting, and distention.
Infertility in women due to pelvic adhesions.
Difficulty moving or pain with movement in severe cases.
prevention: Minimize surgical trauma with careful surgical techniques.
Use of adhesion barriers during surgery.
Prompt treatment of infections and inflammatory conditions.
treatment: Pain management with medications.
Surgical removal of adhesions (adhesiolysis).
Laparoscopic surgery to minimize further adhesion formation.
Physical therapy to improve mobility and reduce pain.

Adjustment disorder.disease_detail: Adjustment disorder is a mental health condition characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to a stressful event or change in a person's life, which are out of proportion to the event and impair daily functioning.
cause: Significant life changes such as divorce, job loss, or moving.
Chronic stress or exposure to stressful environments.
Traumatic events like accidents or natural disasters.
Diagnosis of a serious illness.
symptoms: Sadness or hopelessness.
Anxiety and excessive worry.
Difficulty concentrating.
Changes in sleep patterns or appetite.
Withdrawal from social interactions.
prevention: Develop healthy coping mechanisms for stress.
Seek support from friends, family, or support groups.
Regular exercise and a balanced diet to maintain overall health.
Professional counseling or therapy during times of stress.
treatment: Psychotherapy such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT).
Medications like antidepressants or anti-anxiety drugs.
Stress management techniques and relaxation training.
Support groups or counseling to provide emotional support.

Adrenoleukodystrophy.disease_detail: Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) is a genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and adrenal glands, leading to the buildup of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the brain and adrenal cortex, causing neurological and endocrine problems.
cause: Mutations in the ABCD1 gene on the X chromosome.
Inheritance from a parent carrying the gene mutation.
symptoms: Progressive neurological decline, including loss of vision, hearing, and motor skills.
Adrenal insufficiency leading to symptoms like fatigue, muscle weakness, and skin hyperpigmentation.
Behavioral changes and cognitive decline.
Seizures.
prevention: Genetic counseling and testing for at-risk families.
Early diagnosis and intervention to manage symptoms.
treatment: Lorenzo's oil to reduce VLCFA levels (in some cases).
Adrenal hormone replacement therapy.
Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) in early stages.
Supportive care for neurological symptoms.

Agammaglobulinemia.disease_detail: Agammaglobulinemia is a rare immune disorder where the body produces very few or no antibodies, leading to increased susceptibility to infections. It is often inherited and can be present from birth.
cause: Genetic mutations, particularly in the BTK gene (Bruton tyrosine kinase).
X-linked inheritance pattern in most cases.
Spontaneous genetic mutations.
symptoms: Frequent and severe bacterial infections.
Chronic lung infections or pneumonia.
Sinus infections.
Ear infections.
Diarrhea and gastrointestinal infections.
prevention: There is no known prevention for genetic agammaglobulinemia.
Early diagnosis and treatment to manage infections and prevent complications.
treatment: Regular intravenous or subcutaneous immunoglobulin (IVIG/SCIG) replacement therapy.
Antibiotics to treat and prevent infections.
Monitoring and management of infections and complications.
Gene therapy (experimental).

Agoraphobia.disease_detail: Agoraphobia is an anxiety disorder characterized by intense fear and avoidance of places or situations where escape might be difficult or help unavailable during a panic attack or other distressing symptoms.
cause: Genetic predisposition to anxiety disorders.
Panic disorder or history of panic attacks.
Traumatic or stressful life events.
Imbalance of neurotransmitters in the brain.
symptoms: Fear of leaving home or being in open or enclosed spaces.
Avoidance of crowds, public transportation, and large gatherings.
Anxiety or panic attacks in feared situations.
Physical symptoms like rapid heartbeat, sweating, trembling, and nausea.
Feelings of helplessness and loss of control.
prevention: Early treatment of anxiety and panic disorders.
Stress management techniques and healthy coping strategies.
Regular physical activity and a balanced diet.
Seeking support from mental health professionals when needed.
treatment: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) to address negative thought patterns.
Exposure therapy to gradually face feared situations.
Medications such as SSRIs, benzodiazepines, or beta-blockers.
Support groups and self-help strategies.

Agranulocytosis.disease_detail: Agranulocytosis is a severe condition characterized by a dangerously low number of granulocytes (a type of white blood cell), leading to increased vulnerability to infections. It can be caused by certain medications, infections, or autoimmune disorders.
cause: Drug-induced, especially from medications like antithyroid drugs, antibiotics, and chemotherapy.
Autoimmune disorders such as lupus.
Bone marrow diseases like leukemia.
Severe infections or sepsis.
symptoms: Sudden fever and chills.
Sore throat and mouth ulcers.
Weakness and fatigue.
Increased susceptibility to infections.
Swollen gums and painful swallowing.
prevention: Avoidance of known causative medications if possible.
Regular monitoring of blood counts during high-risk treatments.
Prompt treatment of underlying conditions and infections.
treatment: Immediate discontinuation of causative drugs.
Antibiotics or antifungal medications to treat infections.
Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) to stimulate white blood cell production.
Supportive care, including hospitalization in severe cases.

Albinism.disease_detail: Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes, leading to light-colored appearance and vision problems. It is caused by mutations in genes involved in melanin production.
cause: Mutations in genes responsible for melanin production, such as TYR, OCA2, and others.
Inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
symptoms: Very light skin, hair, and eye color compared to family members.
Vision problems such as nystagmus, strabismus, and photophobia.
Increased risk of skin cancer due to lack of protective pigment.
Impaired depth perception.
prevention: There is no way to prevent albinism, as it is a genetic condition.
Genetic counseling for affected individuals or families.
treatment: Regular eye exams and corrective lenses to manage vision problems.
Protective measures against sun exposure to prevent skin damage and skin cancer.
Counseling and support for individuals and families dealing with the condition.

Alkalosis.disease_detail: Alkalosis is a medical condition characterized by elevated blood pH levels, usually above 7.45, leading to symptoms such as confusion, muscle twitching, and tingling sensations. It can be caused by various factors affecting the body's acid-base balance.
cause: Hyperventilation, leading to excessive loss of carbon dioxide.
Loss of stomach acid through vomiting or nasogastric suctioning.
Excessive intake of alkaline substances such as antacids.
Certain medical conditions like liver disease or hypokalemia.
symptoms: Muscle twitching or spasms.
Hand tremors.
Nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
Confusion or irritability.
Numbness or tingling in the extremities.
prevention: Avoid overuse of antacids or other alkaline substances.
Proper management of underlying medical conditions.
Avoidance of excessive vomiting or purging behaviors.
treatment: Addressing the underlying cause, such as correcting electrolyte imbalances.
Fluid replacement with intravenous solutions.
Medications to control vomiting or respiratory rate if appropriate.
Monitoring of blood pH levels and electrolytes.

Allergic conjunctivitis.disease_detail: Allergic conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva (the membrane lining the eyelids and covering the white part of the eye) due to allergic reactions to substances like pollen, dust mites, or pet dander.
cause: Exposure to allergens such as pollen, dust, or pet dander.
Seasonal changes.
Contact lens use.
Airborne irritants like smoke or pollution.
symptoms: Itchy, watery eyes.
Redness and swelling of the conjunctiva.
Burning or stinging sensation in the eyes.
Sensitivity to light.
Excessive tearing.
prevention: Avoiding known allergens or irritants.
Wearing sunglasses outdoors to protect against pollen and other airborne allergens.
Using air purifiers indoors to reduce allergen exposure.
Regularly cleaning bedding and avoiding dust accumulation.
treatment: Antihistamine eye drops to relieve itching and redness.
Mast cell stabilizers to prevent allergic reactions.
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory eye drops to reduce inflammation.
Cold compresses to soothe irritated eyes.

Allergic reactions.disease_detail: Allergic reactions occur when the immune system overreacts to normally harmless substances, triggering symptoms ranging from mild itching and sneezing to life-threatening anaphylaxis.
cause: Exposure to allergens such as foods, medications, insect stings, or latex.
Genetic predisposition to allergies.
Previous sensitization to allergens.
symptoms: Hives, rash, or itching.
Swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat.
Nasal congestion, sneezing, or runny nose.
Wheezing, coughing, or shortness of breath.
Nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
prevention: Identifying and avoiding known allergens or triggers.
Carrying emergency medication (such as epinephrine auto-injectors) for severe allergic reactions.
Wearing medical alert identification.
Desensitization therapy (immunotherapy) for certain allergies.
treatment: Antihistamines to reduce itching and hives.
Corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and allergic reactions.
Epinephrine injections for severe reactions (anaphylaxis).
Allergen immunotherapy to desensitize the immune system.

Allergic rhinitis.disease_detail: Allergic rhinitis, commonly known as hay fever, is an allergic response to airborne allergens such as pollen, dust mites, or pet dander, leading to symptoms like sneezing, nasal congestion, and itchy, watery eyes.
cause: Exposure to allergens such as pollen, dust mites, pet dander, or mold spores.
Genetic predisposition to allergies.
Environmental factors like air pollution.
symptoms: Sneezing.
Nasal congestion or runny nose (rhinorrhea).
Itchy or watery eyes (allergic conjunctivitis).
Postnasal drip.
Coughing or throat clearing.
prevention: Avoiding known allergens or reducing exposure (e.g., staying indoors during high pollen seasons).
Using air purifiers and HEPA filters to reduce indoor allergens.
Regularly cleaning bedding and vacuuming to minimize dust mites.
Using nasal saline sprays to rinse allergens from the nasal passages.
treatment: Antihistamines to alleviate sneezing, itching, and runny nose.
Nasal corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and nasal congestion.
Decongestants to relieve nasal congestion (short-term use only).
Allergen immunotherapy (allergy shots) for severe or persistent symptoms.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.disease_detail: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that leads to a deficiency in the alpha-1 antitrypsin protein, which can result in lung and liver problems, including emphysema and liver disease.
cause: Inherited genetic mutations in the SERPINA1 gene.
Autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.
symptoms: Shortness of breath, wheezing, and reduced exercise tolerance (lung symptoms).
Chronic cough and sputum production (lung symptoms).
Liver cirrhosis, jaundice, and abdominal swelling (liver symptoms).
Fatigue, weakness, and unintended weight loss.
prevention: There is no way to prevent alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, as it is a genetic disorder.
Genetic counseling for affected individuals or families.
treatment: Alpha-1 antitrypsin augmentation therapy to replace the deficient protein.
Medications to manage symptoms such as bronchodilators and inhaled corticosteroids.
Liver transplant in severe cases of liver disease.
Supportive care to manage complications and improve quality of life.

Alport syndrome.disease_detail: Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities. It is caused by mutations in genes encoding type IV collagen, which is important for the structure and function of the kidneys, ears, and eyes.
cause: Inherited genetic mutations affecting type IV collagen production.
X-linked, autosomal dominant, or autosomal recessive inheritance patterns.
symptoms: Hematuria (blood in the urine), often present from childhood.
Progressive kidney disease leading to proteinuria, hypertension, and eventually kidney failure.
Sensorineural hearing loss, usually starting in late childhood or adolescence.
Eye abnormalities such as lenticonus (abnormal bulging of the lens) and retinopathy.
prevention: There is no way to prevent Alport syndrome, as it is a genetic disorder.
Genetic counseling for affected individuals or families.
treatment: Blood pressure control and medications to slow kidney disease progression.
Hearing aids or cochlear implants for hearing loss.
Regular monitoring of kidney function and management of complications.
Corneal or lens surgery for eye abnormalities.

Alstrom syndrome.disease_detail: Alstrom syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a variety of symptoms including vision and hearing problems, obesity, type 2 diabetes, and heart and kidney issues. It is caused by mutations in the ALMS1 gene.
cause: Genetic mutations in the ALMS1 gene, which plays a role in the structure and function of cilia.
symptoms: Early-onset childhood obesity.
Vision problems such as nystagmus, photophobia, and retinal degeneration.
Hearing loss that worsens over time.
Insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes.
Cardiovascular issues including hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and heart failure.
Kidney problems such as renal failure.
prevention: There is no known way to prevent Alstrom syndrome, as it is a genetic disorder.
Genetic counseling for affected individuals or families.
Alstrom syndrome.doctor: Various specialists including endocrinologists, ophthalmologists, cardiologists, and nephrologists.
treatment: Management of symptoms and complications as they arise.
Regular monitoring and screening for associated conditions.
Supportive care and interventions to improve quality of life.
Research into potential gene therapies or treatments targeting specific symptoms.

Alzheimer.disease_detail: Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurological disorder that causes memory loss, cognitive decline, and changes in behavior. It is the most common cause of dementia.
cause: Exact cause is not fully understood, but believed to involve a combination of genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors.
Abnormal protein deposits in the brain, including beta-amyloid plaques and tau tangles.
symptoms: Memory loss, especially of recent events.
Difficulty in problem-solving or planning.
Confusion about time, place, or people.
Mood and personality changes.
Difficulty speaking, swallowing, and walking in later stages.
prevention: Maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and a balanced diet.
Stay mentally and socially active, engaging in stimulating activities and maintaining social connections.
Manage chronic health conditions such as diabetes, hypertension, and high cholesterol.
Protect the head from injury, as head trauma may increase the risk of Alzheimer's.
treatment: Medications to manage symptoms and slow disease progression, such as cholinesterase inhibitors and memantine.
Therapies to improve cognitive function and manage behavioral symptoms.
Supportive care to assist with daily activities and provide emotional support for patients and caregivers.
Participation in clinical trials investigating new treatments and therapies.

Amebiasis.disease_detail: Amebiasis is an infection of the intestines caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. It can lead to symptoms ranging from mild diarrhea to severe, life-threatening complications such as liver abscesses.
cause: Ingestion of food or water contaminated with Entamoeba histolytica cysts.
symptoms: Mild to severe diarrhea, often with blood or mucus.
Abdominal pain and cramping.
Fatigue and weakness.
Nausea and vomiting.
Fever.
prevention: Practice good hygiene, including handwashing with soap and water before eating or preparing food.
Avoid consuming untreated water or food from questionable sources, particularly in areas with poor sanitation.
Peel or cook raw fruits and vegetables before consumption to kill any potential parasites.
Practice safe sex, as sexual contact can transmit the parasite.
treatment: Antibiotics such as metronidazole or tinidazole to kill the parasite.
Supportive care to manage symptoms such as dehydration and abdominal pain.
Drainage or aspiration of liver abscesses in severe cases.
Follow-up testing to ensure eradication of the parasite.

Amebic liver abscess.disease_detail: Amebic liver abscess is a complication of amebiasis, caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. It is characterized by the formation of pus-filled cavities in the liver and can lead to symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice.
cause: Invasion of the liver by Entamoeba histolytica after ingestion of contaminated food or water.
symptoms: Fever and chills.
Right upper abdominal pain, which may radiate to the shoulder.
Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes).
Nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite.
Enlargement of the liver (hepatomegaly).
prevention: Practice good hygiene and sanitation to prevent amebiasis.
Avoid consumption of untreated water or food from questionable sources.
Peel or cook raw fruits and vegetables before consumption to kill any potential parasites.
Prompt treatment of amebiasis to prevent complications such as liver abscesses.
treatment: Antibiotics such as metronidazole or tinidazole to kill the parasite.
Drainage or aspiration of the liver abscess using ultrasound guidance.
Supportive care to manage symptoms and prevent complications.
Follow-up imaging and testing to ensure resolution of the abscess.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.disease_detail: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness, paralysis, and eventually respiratory failure.
cause: Exact cause is not fully understood, but believed to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Mutations in genes such as C9orf72, SOD1, and TARDBP have been implicated in some cases of familial ALS.
symptoms: Muscle weakness and atrophy, typically beginning in the hands or feet.
Difficulty with tasks such as walking, speaking, swallowing, and fine motor movements.
Muscle twitching (fasciculations) and cramping.
Progressive paralysis, eventually affecting the ability to breathe independently.
Cognitive and behavioral changes in some cases.
prevention: There is currently no known way to prevent ALS.
Avoiding known environmental risk factors such as smoking or exposure to toxins may help reduce the risk.
treatment: Medications such as riluzole and edaravone to slow disease progression.
Physical therapy and assistive devices to maintain mobility and independence.
Speech therapy and dietary modifications to address swallowing difficulties.
Respiratory support and palliative care to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

Anal cancer.disease_detail: Anal cancer is a rare type of cancer that develops in the tissues of the anus. It is often related to infection with the human papillomavirus (HPV) and can present with symptoms such as anal bleeding, pain, and changes in bowel habits.
cause: Infection with high-risk strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV-16 and HPV-18.
Other risk factors include receptive anal intercourse, smoking, and immunosuppression.
symptoms: Anal bleeding or blood in stools.
Pain or discomfort in the anal area.
Changes in bowel habits, such as constipation or diarrhea.
Anal itching or irritation.
Feeling of a lump or mass in the anal region.
prevention: Practice safe sex to reduce the risk of HPV infection.
Get vaccinated against HPV, particularly for individuals in the recommended age groups.
Quit smoking.
Regular screening for anal cancer in high-risk populations, such as individuals with HIV or a history of anal dysplasia.
treatment: Surgery to remove the cancerous tissue, which may involve local excision, wide local excision, or abdominoperineal resection.
Chemotherapy and radiation therapy, either alone or in combination, to shrink tumors and kill cancer cells.
Targeted therapy or immunotherapy for advanced or recurrent anal cancer.
Palliative care to manage symptoms and improve quality of life in advanced cases.

Analgesic nephropathy.disease_detail: Analgesic nephropathy is a chronic kidney disease caused by long-term use of analgesic medications, particularly combination products containing phenacetin, aspirin, and caffeine. It can lead to kidney damage and eventual kidney failure.
cause: Prolonged use of analgesic medications, especially those containing phenacetin, aspirin, and caffeine.
Repeated or high doses of analgesics over many years.
symptoms: Reduced urine output.
Blood in the urine (hematuria).
Swelling of the legs, ankles, or feet (edema).
High blood pressure.
Fatigue and weakness.
prevention: Limiting the use of analgesic medications, particularly those containing phenacetin, aspirin, and caffeine.
Using alternative pain management strategies such as physical therapy, acupuncture, or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
Regular monitoring of kidney function in individuals at risk, especially those with a history of long-term analgesic use.
treatment: Discontinuation of the offending analgesic medication.
Management of symptoms and complications such as high blood pressure and fluid overload.
Dialysis or kidney transplant in advanced cases of kidney failure.
Preventive measures to slow the progression of kidney damage, including blood pressure control and dietary modifications.

Anaphylaxis.disease_detail: Anaphylaxis is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur within minutes of exposure to an allergen. It can affect multiple organ systems and requires immediate medical attention.
cause: Exposure to allergens such as foods (e.g., peanuts, shellfish), medications (e.g., penicillin, NSAIDs), insect stings (e.g., bee venom), or latex.
symptoms: Skin reactions such as hives, itching, or flushed/redness.
Swelling of the lips, tongue, throat, or face (angioedema).
Difficulty breathing, wheezing, or coughing.
Rapid or weak pulse.
Nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
Feeling of impending doom or anxiety.
prevention: Identifying and avoiding known allergens or triggers.
Carrying emergency medication such as epinephrine auto-injectors (e.g., EpiPen) for individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions.
Wearing medical alert identification.
Desensitization therapy (immunotherapy) for certain allergies.
treatment: Prompt administration of epinephrine (adrenaline) to reverse symptoms and stabilize blood pressure.
Antihistamines to reduce itching and hives.
Corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and allergic reactions.
Oxygen therapy and intravenous fluids for supportive care.

Anaplastic thyroid cancer.disease_detail: Anaplastic thyroid cancer is a rare and aggressive form of thyroid cancer that arises from follicular cells in the thyroid gland. It tends to grow and spread rapidly, leading to poor outcomes.
cause: Exact cause is not fully understood, but may involve genetic mutations and exposure to radiation.
symptoms: Rapidly growing neck mass or nodule.
Hoarseness or difficulty speaking.
Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia).
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing.
Neck pain or discomfort.
prevention: There are no specific prevention strategies for anaplastic thyroid cancer.
Avoidance of radiation exposure to the neck area unless medically necessary.
Anaplastic thyroid cancer.doctor: Endocrinologist, Oncologist, Head and Neck Surgeon
treatment: Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible (debulking surgery), often combined with tracheostomy for airway management.
Radiation therapy to shrink the tumor and relieve symptoms.
Chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or immunotherapy for advanced or metastatic disease.
Palliative care to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

Anemia.disease_detail: Anemia is a condition characterized by a deficiency of red blood cells or hemoglobin, leading to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. It can result from various underlying causes and present with symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
cause: Decreased production of red blood cells (e.g., due to nutritional deficiencies, bone marrow disorders).
Increased destruction of red blood cells (e.g., hemolysis, autoimmune disorders).
Blood loss (e.g., gastrointestinal bleeding, menstruation).
symptoms: Fatigue and weakness.
Shortness of breath, especially with exertion.
Pale or yellowish skin (pallor or jaundice).
Dizziness or lightheadedness.
Cold hands and feet.
Headaches and difficulty concentrating.
prevention: Maintaining a healthy diet rich in iron, vitamin B12, and folate.
Treating underlying conditions that may contribute to anemia, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or chronic kidney disease.
Avoiding excessive alcohol consumption, which can impair red blood cell production.
treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying cause of anemia and may include:
- Iron supplementation for iron deficiency anemia.
- Vitamin B12 injections or oral supplements for pernicious anemia or vitamin B12 deficiency.
- Folate supplementation for folate deficiency anemia.
- Blood transfusions for severe or acute anemia.
- Medications to suppress the immune system in cases of autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
- Treatment of underlying conditions causing blood loss or bone marrow suppression.

Angelman syndrome.disease_detail: Angelman syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by developmental delays, intellectual disability, speech impairments, and unique behavioral features such as frequent laughter and smiling. It is caused by a loss of function of the UBE3A gene.
cause: Deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15, or other genetic mutations affecting the same pathway.
symptoms: Developmental delays, with most affected individuals not walking until 2-3 years of age.
Intellectual disability, typically in the moderate to severe range.
Limited or absent speech, with communication often relying on gestures or nonverbal cues.
Ataxia (uncoordinated movement) and tremors.
Hyperactivity, frequent laughter, and a happy demeanor.
Sleep disturbances and seizures.
prevention: There is no way to prevent Angelman syndrome, as it is a genetic disorder.
Genetic counseling for affected individuals or families.
treatment: Management of symptoms and associated conditions such as seizures, sleep disturbances, and behavioral issues.
Physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy to maximize developmental potential and improve quality of life.
Medications to control seizures and improve sleep.
Behavioral interventions and support services for individuals and families.

Anorectal abscess.disease_detail: Anorectal abscess is a collection of pus located near the anus or rectum, often resulting from an infection of the anal glands. It can cause pain, swelling, and sometimes fever.
cause: Bacterial infection of the anal glands or surrounding tissues, often resulting from anal trauma or obstruction of the anal ducts.
symptoms: Pain and swelling around the anus or rectum.
Redness and warmth in the affected area.
Difficulty sitting or moving.
Fever and chills.
Pus or discharge from the abscess.
prevention: Maintain good hygiene, including regular washing of the anal area.
Avoid excessive straining during bowel movements.
Treat conditions such as hemorrhoids or anal fissures promptly to prevent infection.
treatment: Incision and drainage of the abscess to release pus and relieve pressure.
Antibiotics to treat bacterial infection and prevent recurrence.
Warm sitz baths to promote healing and relieve discomfort.
Follow-up evaluation to ensure resolution of the abscess and prevent complications.

Anorexia.disease_detail: Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by an intense fear of gaining weight and a distorted body image, leading to extreme food restriction and often excessive exercise. It can have serious physical and psychological consequences.
cause: Exact cause is not fully understood, but believed to involve a combination of genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors.
Cultural pressure to be thin, societal attitudes toward body image, and media influence may contribute.
symptoms: Significant weight loss or failure to gain weight during growth periods.
Preoccupation with food, calories, dieting, and weight.
Distorted body image, seeing oneself as overweight despite being underweight.
Refusal to maintain a healthy weight, often through severe food restriction.
Excessive exercise or other compensatory behaviors to prevent weight gain.
Social withdrawal and avoidance of social situations involving food.
prevention: Promotion of positive body image and healthy attitudes toward food and weight.
Early detection and intervention for disordered eating behaviors.
Addressing underlying psychological and emotional issues such as low self-esteem or perfectionism.
Education and awareness programs to challenge unrealistic beauty standards and stereotypes.
treatment: Psychotherapy, particularly cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and family-based treatment (FBT).
Nutritional counseling and monitoring to restore weight and normalize eating patterns.
Medical monitoring and management of physical complications such as electrolyte imbalances, heart irregularities, and bone density loss.
Medications such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) for comorbid mood or anxiety disorders.
Support groups and peer support networks for individuals and families affected by anorexia nervosa.

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.disease_detail: An anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury is a common knee injury, particularly among athletes involved in sports that require sudden stops, changes in direction, or jumping. It often occurs due to twisting or hyperextension of the knee.
cause: Sudden twisting or hyperextension of the knee joint.
Direct impact to the knee, such as a collision or fall.
Overuse or repetitive stress on the knee ligaments.
symptoms: A popping sound or sensation at the time of injury.
Pain and swelling around the knee joint.
Instability or a feeling of giving way in the knee, particularly during weight-bearing activities.
Limited range of motion and difficulty walking or bearing weight on the affected leg.
prevention: Participating in proper warm-up and stretching exercises before physical activity.
Strengthening the muscles surrounding the knee joint, particularly the quadriceps and hamstrings.
Using proper techniques and equipment during sports or physical activities to minimize the risk of injury.
Wearing appropriate protective gear, such as knee braces, if recommended.
treatment: Rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) to reduce pain and swelling in the acute phase.
Physical therapy to strengthen the muscles surrounding the knee joint and improve stability.
Bracing or splinting to support the knee during activities.
Surgical reconstruction of the ACL, particularly for individuals who are young, active, or have significant functional instability.

Anthrax.disease_detail: Anthrax is a serious infectious disease caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis. It can occur in three forms: cutaneous (skin), inhalational (lungs), and gastrointestinal (digestive system). Anthrax can be contracted through contact with infected animals or their products, or through bioterrorism.
cause: Infection with the bacterium Bacillus anthracis.
symptoms: Cutaneous anthrax (skin): Painful skin lesions that may develop into ulcers with a black center (eschar), swelling, and fever.
Inhalational anthrax (lungs): Flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, chest discomfort, and shortness of breath, progressing to severe respiratory distress and shock.
Gastrointestinal anthrax (digestive system): Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fever, often progressing rapidly to severe systemic illness.
prevention: Vaccination for individuals at high risk of exposure, such as military personnel or laboratory workers handling anthrax.
Avoiding contact with infected animals or their products, including meat from potentially contaminated animals.
Following appropriate infection control measures in healthcare and laboratory settings.
Maintaining awareness of potential bioterrorism threats and preparedness measures.
treatment: Early administration of antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin, doxycycline, or penicillin.
Supportive care to manage symptoms and prevent complications, including intravenous fluids, oxygen therapy, and medications to support blood pressure.
Surgical debridement or excision of cutaneous lesions in some cases.
Post-exposure prophylaxis with antibiotics for individuals exposed to anthrax.

Anti-glomerular basement membrane diseas.disease_detail: Anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease, also known as Goodpasture's disease, is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the production of autoantibodies against the glomerular basement membrane of the kidneys and the basement membrane of the lungs. It can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage.
cause: Autoimmune reaction leading to the production of autoantibodies against the glomerular basement membrane.
symptoms: Glomerulonephritis: Hematuria (blood in the urine), proteinuria (protein in the urine), edema (swelling), hypertension (high blood pressure), and decreased kidney function.
Pulmonary hemorrhage: Coughing up blood, difficulty breathing, and chest pain.
Fatigue, weakness, and malaise.
Nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite.
prevention: There is no known way to prevent anti-glomerular basement membrane disease.
Early diagnosis and treatment may help prevent progression and complications.
treatment: Immunosuppressive therapy to suppress the autoimmune response, typically with corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide.
Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) to remove circulating autoantibodies.
Supportive care to manage symptoms and complications, including dialysis for kidney failure and mechanical ventilation for severe respiratory distress.
Long-term follow-up and monitoring to assess kidney and lung function and monitor for disease recurrence.

Anti-rust product poisoning.disease_detail: Anti-rust products, often containing substances such as corrosion inhibitors, solvents, and petroleum distillates, can be toxic if ingested, inhaled, or absorbed through the skin. Poisoning can result in a range of symptoms depending on the specific ingredients and route of exposure.
cause: Ingestion, inhalation, or skin contact with toxic substances present in anti-rust products.
symptoms: Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea.
Respiratory symptoms such as coughing, shortness of breath, and chest pain.
Skin irritation, redness, or burns.
Neurological symptoms such as dizziness, headache, confusion, or seizures.
Chemical burns or irritation to the eyes.
prevention: Keep anti-rust products out of reach of children and pets.
Follow label instructions and safety precautions when using anti-rust products.
Use protective equipment such as gloves, goggles, and masks when handling potentially toxic substances.
Store anti-rust products in a well-ventilated area away from heat sources and open flames.
treatment: Treatment depends on the specific toxins involved and the severity of poisoning.
For ingestion, supportive care such as IV fluids, gastric lavage, and activated charcoal to absorb toxins.
For inhalation, removal from the contaminated environment and administration of oxygen therapy if necessary.
For skin exposure, thorough washing with soap and water and application of soothing ointments.
For eye exposure, irrigation with saline solution and evaluation for corneal injury.
In severe cases, antidotes or specific treatments for particular toxins may be necessary.

Anticoagulant rodenticides poisoning.disease_detail: Anticoagulant rodenticides are chemicals commonly used to control rodent populations by preventing blood clotting, leading to fatal bleeding. Accidental or intentional ingestion of these compounds can result in poisoning in humans and animals.
cause: Ingestion of anticoagulant rodenticides, either accidentally or intentionally.
symptoms: Bleeding from the gums, nose, or other mucous membranes.
Blood in the urine or stool.
Excessive bruising or unexplained bleeding.
Weakness, fatigue, and shortness of breath due to anemia.
Chest pain or difficulty breathing if bleeding occurs in the chest or lungs.
Confusion, dizziness, or fainting due to internal bleeding.
prevention: Use alternative methods for rodent control whenever possible, such as traps or natural predators.
Store rodenticides securely out of reach of children and pets.
Follow label instructions and safety precautions when using rodenticides.
Prompt medical attention for suspected cases of poisoning.
treatment: Treatment may include decontamination, supportive care, and specific antidotes depending on the type and severity of poisoning.
Decontamination methods such as activated charcoal to absorb toxins or gastric lavage (stomach pumping) if ingestion is recent.
Administration of vitamin K or fresh frozen plasma to reverse the anticoagulant effects and promote blood clotting.
Blood transfusions if severe bleeding or anemia is present.
Monitoring for complications such as organ damage or shock.
Psychiatric evaluation and support for individuals with intentional poisoning.

Antidiarrheal drug overdose.disease_detail: Antidiarrheal drugs are medications used to control diarrhea by slowing down bowel movements. Overdose of these drugs can lead to serious complications, including constipation, intestinal blockage, and toxicity.
cause: Ingestion of excessive amounts of antidiarrheal medications, either accidentally or intentionally.
symptoms: Constipation and difficulty passing stools.
Abdominal pain, bloating, and distention.
Nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite.
Drowsiness, dizziness, and confusion.
Respiratory depression or difficulty breathing in severe cases.
prevention: Use antidiarrheal medications according to the recommended dosage and duration.
Keep medications out of reach of children and pets.
Do not use antidiarrheal medications to treat diarrhea caused by certain infections (e.g., Clostridium difficile) without medical supervision.
Seek medical attention for persistent or severe diarrhea.
treatment: Treatment may involve supportive care and interventions to manage symptoms and complications.
Discontinuation of the antidiarrheal medication.
Administration of laxatives or stool softeners to relieve constipation and promote bowel movements.
Hydration therapy to prevent dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
Monitoring for signs of intestinal obstruction or other complications.
In severe cases, gastric lavage (stomach pumping) or activated charcoal may be used for decontamination.

Antifreeze poisoning.disease_detail: Antifreeze, also known as coolant, is a liquid used in automotive engines to regulate temperature. It contains ethylene glycol, which is highly toxic if ingested, causing severe kidney damage and potentially fatal complications.
cause: Ingestion of antifreeze, either accidentally or intentionally.
symptoms: Early symptoms may mimic intoxication and include nausea, vomiting, headache, and dizziness.
As ethylene glycol is metabolized, symptoms progress to more severe stages, including kidney damage, metabolic acidosis, and central nervous system depression.
Signs of kidney injury such as decreased urine output, fluid retention, and electrolyte abnormalities.
Neurological symptoms such as confusion, seizures, coma, or death.
prevention: Keep antifreeze containers tightly sealed and stored out of reach of children and pets.
Dispose of antifreeze properly and do not pour it onto the ground where it can contaminate soil and water sources.
Use products with safer alternatives to ethylene glycol, such as propylene glycol.
Seek immediate veterinary attention if pets ingest antifreeze, as they are particularly susceptible to toxicity.
treatment: Prompt medical attention is essential to prevent severe complications and death.
Treatment may involve decontamination, supportive care, and specific antidotes.
Administering activated charcoal or gastric lavage (stomach pumping) if ingestion is recent to prevent further absorption of ethylene glycol.
Administering antidotes such as fomepizole or ethanol to inhibit the metabolism of ethylene glycol.
Supportive measures to maintain hydration, correct electrolyte imbalances, and support kidney function.
Hemodialysis in severe cases to remove ethylene glycol and its toxic metabolites from the bloodstream.

Antisocial personality disorder.disease_detail: Antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) is a mental health condition characterized by a pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others. Individuals with ASPD may engage in behaviors such as lying, manipulation, impulsivity, aggression, and disregard for safety or social norms.
cause: Exact cause is not fully understood, but likely involves a combination of genetic, biological, environmental, and psychosocial factors.
Early childhood experiences such as abuse, neglect, or exposure to violence may contribute to the development of ASPD.
symptoms: Disregard for social norms and laws, leading to repeated criminal behavior.
Deceitfulness, lying, and manipulation for personal gain or pleasure.
Impulsivity, irresponsibility, and failure to plan ahead.
Aggressiveness, hostility, and frequent conflicts with others.
Lack of empathy or remorse for the harm caused to others.
Disregard for safety, both for oneself and others.
Consistent irresponsibility and failure to maintain stable work or relationships.
prevention: Early intervention and treatment for conduct disorder or other behavioral problems in childhood.
Providing a supportive and nurturing environment for children, addressing trauma or adverse experiences when present.
Educational programs and interventions aimed at promoting empathy, social skills, and conflict resolution.
Access to mental health services and treatment for individuals at risk or displaying early signs of antisocial behavior.
treatment: Psychotherapy, particularly cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), to address maladaptive behaviors, attitudes, and interpersonal skills.
Medications such as antidepressants or mood stabilizers to manage co-occurring symptoms such as depression or impulsivity.
Substance abuse treatment if comorbid substance use disorders are present.
Management of legal issues and involvement with the criminal justice system.
Supportive services and social skills training to improve functioning and reduce risk of harm to self and others.

Aortic arch syndrome.disease_detail: Aortic arch syndrome refers to a group of conditions that affect the blood vessels branching off the aortic arch, including the brachiocephalic artery, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. These conditions often involve inflammation or narrowing of these vessels, leading to reduced blood flow to the head, neck, and upper extremities.
cause: Atherosclerosis (hardening and narrowing of the arteries) is a common underlying cause of aortic arch syndrome.
Other causes include vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels), congenital abnormalities, trauma, or radiation therapy.
symptoms: Symptoms vary depending on the specific condition affecting the blood vessels.
Common symptoms may include dizziness, headache, visual disturbances, weakness, numbness, or pain in the head, neck, or upper extremities.
In severe cases, reduced blood flow to vital organs can lead to stroke, myocardial infarction, or limb ischemia.
prevention: Maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise, a balanced diet, and avoidance of smoking.
Manage underlying conditions such as hypertension, diabetes, or high cholesterol to reduce the risk of atherosclerosis.
Prompt diagnosis and treatment of vasculitis or other inflammatory conditions.
treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying cause and severity of symptoms.
Medications may include antiplatelet agents, anticoagulants, or medications to control blood pressure and cholesterol levels.
In cases of severe narrowing or blockage, surgical interventions such as angioplasty with stent placement or bypass grafting may be necessary to restore blood flow.
Management of associated conditions such as hypertension or diabetes.
Regular monitoring and follow-up to assess treatment effectiveness and prevent complications.

Aortic dissection.disease_detail: Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition characterized by a tear in the inner layer of the aorta, the largest artery in the body. This tear allows blood to flow between the layers of the aortic wall, leading to separation of the layers and potential rupture of the aorta.
cause: Aortic dissection often occurs in individuals with underlying risk factors such as hypertension, atherosclerosis, connective tissue disorders, or a family history of aortic disease.
Acute trauma or sudden deceleration injuries can also lead to aortic dissection.
symptoms: Sudden, severe chest pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen.
Pain described as tearing, ripping, or sharp in nature.
Other symptoms may include shortness of breath, difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, or weakness or paralysis in the limbs if blood flow to vital organs or extremities is compromised.
prevention: Control risk factors such as hypertension, high cholesterol, and smoking.
Regular monitoring and management of connective tissue disorders or other conditions associated with aortic disease.
Seek prompt medical attention for symptoms of aortic dissection or other cardiovascular emergencies.
Aortic dissection.doctor: Vascular Surgeon, Cardiothoracic Surgeon, Emergency Physician
treatment: Emergency medical treatment is essential to prevent complications and reduce mortality.
Immediate stabilization with medications to control blood pressure and heart rate.
Surgical intervention to repair the aorta and prevent further dissection or rupture, often involving open surgery or endovascular repair.
Ongoing management of blood pressure and other cardiovascular risk factors.
Long-term surveillance and monitoring to detect recurrent dissection or complications.

Aortic regurgitation.disease_detail: Aortic regurgitation, also known as aortic insufficiency, is a heart valve disorder characterized by the leakage of blood from the aorta back into the left ventricle during diastole (the resting phase of the cardiac cycle). This can lead to volume overload of the left ventricle and potentially heart failure.
cause: Aortic regurgitation can result from a variety of underlying causes, including congenital abnormalities, infections (e.g., endocarditis), connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome), rheumatic fever, or degenerative changes in the valve leaflets.
symptoms: In mild cases, there may be no symptoms initially.
As the condition progresses, symptoms may include fatigue, dyspnea (shortness of breath), palpitations, chest pain, or exertional syncope (fainting).

In severe cases, symptoms of heart failure such as orthopnea (difficulty breathing while lying flat), paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (sudden awakening with shortness of breath), and peripheral edema (swelling in the legs) may develop.
